page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Hosni Mubarak's rule

rev.diff:
Line 238: Line 238:
[[File:Protester on pavement in Tahrir.jpg|thumb|left|An anti-government protester in Tahrir Square. The placard reads "''Leave leave and rest assured, the chaos will leave with you, leave leave.''"]]
[[File:Protester on pavement in Tahrir.jpg|thumb|left|An anti-government protester in Tahrir Square. The placard reads "''Leave leave and rest assured, the chaos will leave with you, leave leave.''"]]
â
At least 70 people were wounded when hundreds of residents attacked the police station in Khargah to demand the ouster of a police official who had a reputation for heavy-handedness. Police then opened fire on the protesters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110208/D9L8NDD03.html |title=Freed young leader energizes Egyptian protests |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> Authorities said that 11 people were said to have been killed across the country.<ref name="aljazbloglive7feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/06/live-blog-feb-7-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 7 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=7 February 2011}}</ref> The United Nations says it is more than 300.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} MENA reports Mubarak has set up two committees to draw up changes to the constitution.
+
At least 70 people were wounded when hundreds of residents attacked the police station in Khargah to demand the ouster of a police official who had a reputation for heavy-handedness. Police then opened fire on the protesters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110208/D9L8NDD03.html |title=Freed young leader energizes Egyptian protests |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> Authorities said that 11 people were said to have been killed across the country.<ref name="aljazbloglive7feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/06/live-blog-feb-7-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 7 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=7 February 2011}}</ref> The United Nations says it is more than 300.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hrw.org/en/news/2011/02/08/egypt-documented-death-toll-protests-tops-300 |title=Egypt: Documented Death Toll From Protests Tops 300 | Human Rights Watch |publisher=Hrw.org |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref> Two committees will be formed to amend the constitution and be responsible for carrying out new agreements, according to Suleiman.<ref>http://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/2011/02/massive-demonstrations-in-cairo-draw-thousands.html</ref>
Finance Minister Samir Radwan said 6.5 billion [[Egyptian pounds]] (US$960 million) will be allocated to cover a 15 per cent raise in pensions and salaries for government employees. This decision was made at the first Cabinet meeting since the protests began. One protester said that protests would not end soon because of increasing concessions that the regime offers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110207/D9L7VGTG1.html |title=Egypt approves 15 percent raise for govt employees |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> While banks have reopened, schools and the stock exchange remain closed. The [[Egyptian Exchange|Egyptian Stock Exchange]] said it would resume work on 13 February.<ref name="aljazbloglive7feb" /> Minister of Antiquities Zahi Hawass announced that artifacts damaged by looters would be restored over the next five days. He also said that steps were being taken to reopen Egypt's famed archaeological sites, which have been closed since pro-democracy protests started two weeks ago. Among the objects damaged was a statue of King Tutankhamun standing on a panther and a wooden sarcophagus from the New Kingdom period, dating to roughly 3,500 years ago. The museum, which is adjacent to the anti-government protests in downtown Cairo, was being guarded by the army.<ref name="aljazbloglive7feb" /> Former minister of the interior [[Habib Ibrahim El Adly|Habib El-Adli]] faced prosecution in a military court over giving orders to fire at protesters and obstructing peace in Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/07/us-egypt-adli-idUSTRE7163D420110207 |title=Egypt's ex-police chief appears before prosecutors |publisher=Reuters |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> his role in the 31 December 2010 bombing of al-Qiddissin Church in Alexandria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ikhwanweb.com/article.php?id=27982|title=Former Interior Minister Habib El Adly Accused of Being Involved in Alex Qiddisin's Church Bombings|publisher=Ikhwan Web|date=7 February 2011 |accessdate=8 February 2011}}</ref>
Finance Minister Samir Radwan said 6.5 billion [[Egyptian pounds]] (US$960 million) will be allocated to cover a 15 per cent raise in pensions and salaries for government employees. This decision was made at the first Cabinet meeting since the protests began. One protester said that protests would not end soon because of increasing concessions that the regime offers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110207/D9L7VGTG1.html |title=Egypt approves 15 percent raise for govt employees |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> While banks have reopened, schools and the stock exchange remain closed. The [[Egyptian Exchange|Egyptian Stock Exchange]] said it would resume work on 13 February.<ref name="aljazbloglive7feb" /> Minister of Antiquities Zahi Hawass announced that artifacts damaged by looters would be restored over the next five days. He also said that steps were being taken to reopen Egypt's famed archaeological sites, which have been closed since pro-democracy protests started two weeks ago. Among the objects damaged was a statue of King Tutankhamun standing on a panther and a wooden sarcophagus from the New Kingdom period, dating to roughly 3,500 years ago. The museum, which is adjacent to the anti-government protests in downtown Cairo, was being guarded by the army.<ref name="aljazbloglive7feb" /> Former minister of the interior [[Habib Ibrahim El Adly|Habib El-Adli]] faced prosecution in a military court over giving orders to fire at protesters and obstructing peace in Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/07/us-egypt-adli-idUSTRE7163D420110207 |title=Egypt's ex-police chief appears before prosecutors |publisher=Reuters |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> his role in the 31 December 2010 bombing of al-Qiddissin Church in Alexandria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ikhwanweb.com/article.php?id=27982|title=Former Interior Minister Habib El Adly Accused of Being Involved in Alex Qiddisin's Church Bombings|publisher=Ikhwan Web|date=7 February 2011 |accessdate=8 February 2011}}</ref>
